Read text aloud in simple JavaScript













Anirudh Munipalli



·Follow




Published inStackademic



·

2 min read·
Aug 8








--










Listen









Share












Photo by Michael Dziedzic on UnsplashBasics of Speech synthesis, and how to implement it
We have all seen software that convert text to speech.
We can do a similar thing in JavaScript.
This is an in-built feature supported by most major browsers.
So, let’s get straight to it.
A basic text to speech
It is surprisingly simple to create a basic text reader and can be done in a few lines.
First, create an utterance of what to say:
var dialogue = new SpeechSynthesisUtterance("Hello World. \
                        How are you? I can speak!")Then, just let the browser say it out.
speechSynthesis.speak(dialogue)The voice does sound robotic, and there is only one voice.
We can’t do anything about the robotic voice, but we can change the voice.
Getting a list of available voices
First, we need to check if the voices are available:
speechSynthesis.onvoiceschanged = voicesChangedLet’s create the voicesChanged function:
function voicesChanged(){
  voices = speechSynthesis.getVoices()
  for(let i = 0; i < voices.length; i++){
    console.log(voices[i])
  }
}Run the code. You can see many voices available. These might differ from browser to browser though.
Find a voice that seems good to you and take note of it’s name. I’ll try “Microsoft Heera — English (India)” (I’m using Edge).
Within the for loop in the voicesChanged function, create an if statement:
    if(voices[i].name == "Microsoft Heera - English (India)"){
      // Code
    }Over here, let’s create a new code utterance (just like the previous section).
var dialogue = new SpeechSynthesisUtterance("Hello. This \
      is a different voice. How does it sound")
dialogue.voice = voices[i]
speechSynthesis.speak(dialogue)Notice the dialogue.voice in the code. That is where we set the voice to a new one.
You can even change the volume and pitch of the voices.
Play around with speech synthesis. It expands the possibilities of what is possible in browsers. You don’t even have to code or train your own AI.

I have already written articles about console, screen recorder, and browser history in JavaScript.

<figcaption class="no fc np na nb nq nr be b bf z dt">Photo by <a class="af ns" href="https://unsplash.com/@lazycreekimages?utm_source=medium&utm_medium=referral" rel="noopener ugc nofollow" target="_blank">Michael Dziedzic</a> on <a class="af ns" href="https://unsplash.com/?utm_source=medium&utm_medium=referral" rel="noopener ugc nofollow" target="_blank">Unsplash</a></figcaption></figure><p id="fb0c" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Basics of Speech synthesis, and how to implement it</p>
<p id="417a" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">We have all seen software that convert text to speech.</p>
<p id="d2c4" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">We can do a similar thing in JavaScript.</p>
<p id="7201" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">This is an in-built feature supported by most major browsers.</p>
<p id="29e2" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">So, let’s get straight to it.</p>
<h2 id="8f6a" class="or os gr be ot ou ov dx ow ox oy dz oz oe pa pb pc oi pd pe pf om pg ph pi pj bj">A basic text to speech</h2>
<p id="6a97" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw pk ny nz oa pl oc od oe pm og oh oi pn ok ol om po oo op oq gk bj">It is surprisingly simple to create a basic text reader and can be done in a few lines.</p>
<p id="c832" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">First, create an utterance of what to say:</p>
<pre class="pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw bo px ba bj"><span id="e491" class="py os gr pv b bf pz qa l qb qc">var dialogue = new SpeechSynthesisUtterance("Hello World. \<br>
                        How are you? I can speak!")</span></pre><p id="ac2b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Then, just let the browser say it out.</p>
<pre class="pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw bo px ba bj"><span id="066f" class="py os gr pv b bf pz qa l qb qc">speechSynthesis.speak(dialogue)</span></pre><p id="6942" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">The voice does sound robotic, and there is only one voice.</p>
<p id="3978" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">We can’t do anything about the robotic voice, but we can change the voice.</p>
<h2 id="da8d" class="or os gr be ot ou ov dx ow ox oy dz oz oe pa pb pc oi pd pe pf om pg ph pi pj bj">Getting a list of available voices</h2>
<p id="9bcf" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw pk ny nz oa pl oc od oe pm og oh oi pn ok ol om po oo op oq gk bj">First, we need to check if the voices are available:</p>
<pre class="pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw bo px ba bj"><span id="2d32" class="py os gr pv b bf pz qa l qb qc">speechSynthesis.onvoiceschanged = voicesChanged</span></pre><p id="3211" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Let’s create the <code class="cw qd qe qf pv b">voicesChanged</code> function:</p>
<pre class="pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw bo px ba bj"><span id="9406" class="py os gr pv b bf pz qa l qb qc">function voicesChanged(){<br>
  voices = speechSynthesis.getVoices()<br>
  for(let i = 0; i < voices.length; i++){<br>
    console.log(voices[i])<br>
  }<br>
}</span></pre><p id="fde1" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Run the code. You can see many voices available. These might differ from browser to browser though.</p>
<p id="d1a6" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Find a voice that seems good to you and take note of it’s name. I’ll try “Microsoft Heera — English (India)” (I’m using Edge).</p>
<p id="5a4b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Within the for loop in the <code class="cw qd qe qf pv b">voicesChanged</code> function, create an if statement:</p>
<pre class="pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw bo px ba bj"><span id="2175" class="py os gr pv b bf pz qa l qb qc">    if(voices[i].name == "Microsoft Heera - English (India)"){<br>
      // Code<br>
    }</span></pre><p id="9529" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Over here, let’s create a new code utterance (just like the previous section).</p>
<pre class="pp pq pr ps pt pu pv pw bo px ba bj"><span id="8bea" class="py os gr pv b bf pz qa l qb qc">var dialogue = new SpeechSynthesisUtterance("Hello. This \<br>
      is a different voice. How does it sound")<br>
dialogue.voice = voices[i]<br>
speechSynthesis.speak(dialogue)</span></pre><p id="265c" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Notice the <code class="cw qd qe qf pv b">dialogue.voice</code> in the code. That is where we set the voice to a new one.</p>
<p id="d5ae" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">You can even change the volume and pitch of the voices.</p>
<p id="f46f" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Play around with speech synthesis. It expands the possibilities of what is possible in browsers. You don’t even have to code or train your own AI.</p>
<p id="df5b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nt nu gr nv b nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq gk bj">Please show appreciation for this article by clapping.
